thread.title: Car crash fells power lines at Wakefield, closes highway
thread.title_full: Car crash fells power lines at Wakefield, closes highway

author: Jessica Long
title: Car crash fells power lines at Wakefield, closes highway
text:
Car crash fells power lines at Wakefield, closes highway JESSICA LONG Last updated 10:58, February 3 2017 Nelson Marlborough Rescue Helicopter 
Emergency services at the scene of a dramatic crash in Wakefield where a car collided with a power pole pulling live wires over the road. 
The driver of a vehicle which slammed into a concrete power pole pulling wires over a Wakefield road is "lucky" to come away uninjured, emergency services say. 
The driver's car left the road at the intersection of Wakefield-Kohatu Highway (SH6) and Wai-iti Valley Rd and hit a power pole pulling live wires over the road about 6pm on Thursday. 
Emergency services were called and the road was closed for about three hours. 
The national police media centre said the road was closed due to the live power lines on the road, and a second power pole was also in danger of toppling over. 
The driver of the vehicle was not injured. 
Diversions were put in place along Wai-iti Valley Rd until about 9pm. 
Nelson Tasman network manager Murray Hendrickson said the crash did not cut the power. A crew cut the power at 6.50pm and worked to replace the pole by 10.30pm. 
Hendrickson said the live wires highlighted a safety issue and urged the public to remember to never approach power lines. 
He said fallen lines could be live and if people saw fallen lines they should "steer clear, keep others away and report it immediately." 
Nelson Marlborough Rescue Helicopter pilot Tim Douglas-Clifford said the chopper came across the incident as it was coming back from Upper Buller Gorge to another road accident just after 5pm. Ad Feedback 
He said the driver was "lucky" to come away uninjured from the crash and there was no need to transport him to hospital. 
Douglas-Clifford said the helicopter was earlier called to a car crash between Inangahua Junction and Murchison, but was not needed. 
No one was trapped or injured in the crash. Police said one person suffered shock as a result of the crash, and the two vehicles in the incident blocked both lanes of traffic.
